Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Radar Deployment for RELAMPAGO (Remote sensing of Electrification, Lightning, And Mesoscale/microscale Processes with Adaptive Ground Observations)
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding for the deployment of the Colorado State University C-band radar to a large field campaign in Argentina. The Remote Sensing Electrification, Lightning and Mesoscale/microscale processes with Adaptive ground observations (known colloquially as RELAMPAGO) experiment is intended to observe some of the most intense thunderstorms in the world. The addition of the C-band radar will help to fill in an observational gap and allow researchers to determine characteristics of precipitation particles in these thunderstorms. This is an international campaign, but the impacts to forecasting severe weather in the United States are significant. The researchers will be able to test whether the models and theories that have been derived for storms in the Great Plains will hold for those in Argentina. If there are differences, that may point to changes that can be made in models to make them more accurate.

The RELAMPAGO field campaign will take place in late 2018 near Cordoba, Argentina. The Colorado State University C-band radar will be paired with two other C-band radars to provide coverage of the region downstream from orographic terrain where large thunderstorm complexes initiate. The CSU C-band radar will focus on efforts to understand the intensification and growth of convection and the generation of hazardous convective weather. The deployment will be extended beyond the main field campaign timeline in tandem with the Department of Energy C-band radar in an effort to collect as many cases as possible.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project accomplished the deployment of the Colorado State University, C-Band dual-polarization radar for the RELAMPAGO experiment.  The CSU C-Pol radar deployment was done to collect dual-polarization precipitation radar measurements during RELAMPAGO to observe convective initiation, severe weather, and convective upscale.  Radar disassembly from home base, transportation, radar integration, assembly and operations of the radar were facilitated by this project. 

 

Documenting the processes reveled by polarimetric measurements that impact heavy rain producing storms has very high scientific and societal importance. RELAMPAGO domain provides the best opportunity to observe and document the physical processes leading to deep convection and High Impact Weather. Deployment of the CSU-C band radar accomplished this goal with flying colors.   One of the most important accomplishment of this project was to demonstrate that C band radars can be used for studying deep convection, by managing the attenuation in precipitation.

 

The radar operated continuously, throughout the program and many significant weather events were observed by CHIVO, either by itself, or, in coordination with other instruments in the field.  The radar also provided excellent training ground for graduate students in radar operation planning and deployment.

 

 

RELAMPAGO experiment and the CHIVO radar deployment has shown the value of networking smaller size and higher frequency radars in monitoring extreme weather and documenting rapid growth storms. The radar deployment, through its engagement of graduate students, and collaboration with local scientists, provides immense opportunity for educational and international exchange.  A pool of graduate students got in-depth experience, how to manage the operation of a large scientific instrument such as a dual-polarization C band weather radar. In addition, the students and the scientists involved learned the value of international scientific collaboration, not just the natural environment provided by the storms in Argentina but the rich scientific background that the local scientists have about the science questions related to the local environment.
